message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lifelong aspirin therapy as monotherapy for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention is recommended for patients with a history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, including transient ischemic attack. Therefore, option (D) is the most appropriate patient to be started on lifelong aspirin therapy. Option (A) just had a drug-eluting coronary stent placed and should be on dual antiplatelet therapy. Option (B) already has anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation and may not need aspirin therapy. Option (C) had a hemorrhagic stroke and should not be started on aspirin therapy due to the increased risk of bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to current evidence-based recommendations, patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or at high risk for ASCVD should consider taking low-dose aspirin. Of the options given, the patient with a history of transient ischemic attack is at high risk for ASCVD and would be a candidate for aspirin therapy. The other options have either a recent history of a bleeding event (option C) or a contraindication to aspirin due to recent placement of a drug-eluting stent (option A) or a high risk of bleeding due to diabetic status and atrial fibrillation (option B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the 2019 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease, patients with a history of a transient ischemic attack or stroke should be started on low-dose aspirin for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. All other options have contraindications to starting aspirin monotherapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lifelong aspirin therapy is recommended for secondary prevention in patients who have had a previous cardiovascular event, such as a transient ischemic attack, as in option D. This recommendation does not apply to patients who have had a hemorrhagic stroke, as in option C. Option A is not recommended for aspirin therapy within 12 months after drug-eluting stent placement due to increased bleeding risk. Option B may require anticoagulant therapy instead of aspirin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate patient for lifelong aspirin as monotherapy for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention is the 63-year-old male with a history of transient ischemic attack, as this indicates a high risk for future cardiovascular events. Aspirin is not recommended for the other patients listed: the 75-year-old male with a recent drug-eluting coronary stent should receive dual antiplatelet therapy; the 67-year-old female with diabetes and atrial fibrillation may require anticoagulation instead; and the 83-year-old female with a history of hemorrhagic stroke should avoid aspirin due to increased bleeding risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to current guidelines, lifelong aspirin as monotherapy for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention is only recommended for patients with established cardiovascular disease or those at high risk. The patient with a history of transient ischemic attack is at high risk and should be started on aspirin therapy, while the other options have contraindications or lack indication for aspirin therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The American Heart Association recommends aspirin for primary prevention in patients aged 50-59 years who have a ≥10% 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), no history of bleeding, and an anticipated 10-year life expectancy. Aspirin for secondary prevention is recommended for patients with a history of ASCVD. Option A had a stent placed too recently, option B has atrial fibrillation and would require anticoagulation, option C has a history of hemorrhagic stroke, which is a contraindication to aspirin use. Option D has a history of a transient ischemic attack, which qualifies as a history of ASCVD and would necessitate aspirin use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lifelong aspirin therapy for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention is recommended for patients with a history of a cardiovascular event, such as a transient ischemic attack. Patients with a history of hemorrhagic stroke are at increased risk of recurrent bleeding and are not candidates for aspirin therapy. Patients with recent coronary stent placement or atrial fibrillation may benefit from antiplatelet therapy, but aspirin alone is not the recommended therapy in these cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin is recommended for primary prevention in patients with a high risk of cardiovascular disease, such as those with a history of transient ischemic attack. For secondary prevention, aspirin is recommended for patients with a history of myocardial infarction or stroke, but not for those with a history of hemorrhagic stroke or recent drug-eluting coronary stent placement. Atrial fibrillation is not an indication for primary prevention with aspirin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin as primary prevention has been shown to reduce risk of nonfatal myocardial infarction, but not stroke, in patients with no history of cardiovascular disease. Aspirin as secondary prevention has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease. Of the options provided, only the 63-year-old male has a history of a transient ischemic attack, which qualifies him for secondary prevention with aspirin. The other options either have recently undergone a procedure or have a history of bleeding which makes starting aspirin a risk.
